title: 104_hr2164
content: The Act may be cited as the "Eliminate the Magnet for Illegal Immigration Act of 1995" and includes a table of contents. The "Eliminate the Magnet for Illegal Immigration Act of 1995" includes provisions to increase investigators for enforcing employer sanctions, labor standards, and antidiscrimination provisions. It also includes measures to reduce employment verification documents, increase penalties for document fraud, and enhance employer education on hiring violations. Additionally, the Act aims to increase civil money penalties for hiring, recruiting, and referral violations. The Act aims to increase penalties for labor standards violations, unfair immigration-related employment practices, and immigration-related discrimination. It also includes provisions to increase INS investigators for enforcing employer sanctions. For fiscal years 1996 and 1997, additional funds are authorized for hiring, training, and salaries of Immigration and Naturalization Service personnel. This includes increasing the number of investigators by 365 full-time positions each year and providing resources for enforcing employer sanctions. The focus is on investigating violations in areas with high priority. SEC. 3. INCREASE IN DEPARTMENT OF LABOR INVESTIGATORS TO ENFORCE LABOR STANDARDS. The focus is on increasing the number of Department of Labor investigators to enforce labor standards, with priority given to areas with high concentrations of unauthorized aliens who are employed. For fiscal years 1996 and 1997, additional funding is authorized for hiring, training, and salaries of Employment Standards Administration personnel at the Department of Labor. This includes increasing the number of investigators by 300 full-time positions each year and providing necessary support for enforcing labor standards. SEC. 4. INCREASE IN INVESTIGATORS IN OFFICE OF SPECIAL COUNSEL FOR IMMIGRATION-RELATED UNFAIR EMPLOYMENT PRACTICES TO ENFORCE ANTIDISCRIMINATION PROVISIONS. Investigators will focus on violations of labor standards in areas with high concentrations of unauthorized aliens. For fiscal years 1996 and 1997, additional funding is authorized for hiring, training, and salaries of personnel in the Office of Special Counsel for Immigration-Related Unfair Employment Practices. This includes increasing the number of investigators by 50 positions and providing necessary support for enforcing immigration-related antidiscrimination provisions. The additional investigators authorized for hiring in the Office of Special Counsel will investigate and prosecute violations of immigration-related antidiscrimination provisions. SEC. 5. SUBPOENA AND RELATED AUTHORITY. Subpoena authority for designated immigration officers and the Secretary of Labor is amended to allow compelling witnesses and evidence production. The Nationality Act is amended to include a new section at the end. The Nationality Act is amended to include a new section at the end, granting the secretary of labor authority. The Secretary of Labor is granted subpoena authority to compel witness testimony and document production for immigration program investigations. The Secretary can administer oaths, examine witnesses, and seek court orders for non-compliance with subpoenas. The table of contents of the Act is amended to include a new section after section 293. SEC. 6. REDUCING THE NUMBER OF EMPLOYMENT VERIFICATION DOCUMENTS. Amendments are made to section 274A(b)(1) of the Immigration and Nationality Act regarding employment verification documents. The changes include adding new clauses, updating security features, and specifying the effective date for hiring practices. Increasing penalties for document fraud. Increasing penalties for document fraud, the Criminal Penalties section of the title 18, United States Code, has been amended to impose harsher punishments for fraud and misuse of government-issued identification documents. The maximum term of imprisonment for such offenses has been increased to 10 years, with higher penalties of 15 years for offenses committed to facilitate drug trafficking crimes and 20 years for those committed to facilitate acts of international terrorism. Additionally, changes to the sentencing levels will be implemented by the United States Sentencing Commission. The guidelines will be updated to increase base offense levels for document fraud under section 1028(a) of title 18, United States Code. Civil penalties under the Immigration and Nationality Act will be amended to include penalties for failing to present required documents upon arrival in the United States. The Attorney General may waive penalties for an alien who knowingly violates document fraud laws if granted asylum or withholding of deportation. Documents prepared with false information or material misrepresentation are considered falsely made. The amendments made to the Immigration and Nationality Act include changes to document fraud laws and effective dates for violations. Additionally, joint efforts by the INS and the Department of Labor are aimed at investigating employer sanctions and labor standards. The Secretary of Labor, in consultation with the Commissioner of Immigration and Naturalization, will establish programs to investigate violations of employer sanctions and labor standards. A performance review will be conducted to assess the effectiveness of these programs in targeting industries likely to violate both employer sanctions and labor standards. Additionally, there will be employer education initiatives. The Attorney General, along with other government officials, will conduct a nationwide program to educate employers on their responsibilities regarding employer sanctions, labor standards, and immigration-related antidiscrimination provisions. Additionally, civil money penalties for hiring, recruiting, and referral violations will be increased. The Immigration and Nationality Act is amended to increase penalties for violations, with fines ranging from $1,000 to $25,000. These amendments apply to violations occurring after a 6-month period from the enactment of the Act. The Immigration and Nationality Act is amended to increase penalties for willful or repeated violations of labor standards with unauthorized aliens, with fines doubled for violations occurring within a 10-year period of a final determination. The Immigration and Nationality Act is amended to increase civil money penalties for unfair immigration-related employment practices, with fines doubled for violations occurring within a 10-year period of a final determination. Effective date for these amendments is after a 6-month period from the enactment of the Act. The Immigration and Nationality Act is amended to increase civil money penalties for unfair immigration-related employment practices, with fines doubled for violations occurring within a 10-year period of a final determination. Effective date for these amendments is after a 6-month period from the enactment of the Act. Clause (iv) of section 274B(g)(2)(B) is amended to adjust the penalty amounts for violations. The Attorney General will conduct a study on the impact of increased enforcement of employer sanctions on workplace discrimination based on national origin or citizenship since 1989. A report with recommendations on preventing such discrimination must be submitted to Congress within 2 years of the Act's enactment. The Act defines key terms such as employer sanctions, immigration-related antidiscrimination provisions, labor standards, and unauthorized alien. The term is defined in section 274A(h)(3) of the Immigration and Nationality Act (8 U.S.C. 1324a(h)(3)).
